Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the sources must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Do not take a position, or the position is vague or must be inferred.

· Equivocate or summarize other’s arguments but not the student’s (e.g., some people say it’s good, some people say it’s bad).

· State an obvious fact rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Since the USPS has lost revenue, the organization has been prompted to consider cutting back on delivery days and other services.”

Address the topic of the prompt but do not take a position

· “There are advantages to restructuring the USPS, but there are some disadvantages to doing it as well.”

Address the topic of the prompt but state an obvious fact as a claim

· “The USPS has an impact on U.S history and people’s daily lives.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Respond to the prompt by developing a position on whether the USPS should be restructured to meet the needs of a changing world, and if so, how rather than restate or rephrase the prompt.

· Clearly take a position rather than just stating that there are pros/cons.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible position that responds to the prompt

· “While we should not discount the progress made in the past decades that has facilitated a transition to faster and sleeker technologies, it is also paramount that we support and maintain traditions and symbols of the American dream like the USPS by applying modern principles and revamping the company’s image and organization.”

· “The USPS should be restructured to catch up to technology because USPS can provide everything that FedEx or UPS can, not only better, but it does the job of an email with more emotion than any other communication service in America.”

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence from or references at least two of the provided sources [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on summary or description of sources rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence from or references at least three of the provided sources [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence from at least three of the provided sources to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the sources to build an argument.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence from at least three of the provided sources to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the sources to build an argument.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or does not develop a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their argument, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other arguments (“While some may argue that…” OR “Some people say…”).

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation by doing any of the following:

1. Crafting a nuanced argument by consistently identifying and exploring complexities or tensions across the sources.

2. Articulating the implications or limitations of an argument (either the student’s argument or arguments conveyed in the sources) by situating it within a broader context.

3. Making effective rhetorical choices that consistently strengthen the force and impact of the student’s argument.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:

Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Fail to address the rhetorical choices the writer of the passage makes.

· Describe or repeat the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Kennedy uses rhetorical choices to explain why his argument is important.”

Make a claim but do not address the writer’s rhetorical choices

· “Kennedy says that the steel industry’s focus on increasing prices does not support the common good of the nation.”

Repeat provided information from the passage

· “According to Kennedy, ‘there is no justification for an increase in steel prices.’”

Responses that earn this point:

· Respond to the prompt rather than restate or rephrase the prompt and clearly articulate a defensible thesis about the rhetorical choices Kennedy makes to achieve his purpose.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible thesis that analyzes the writer’s rhetorical choices

· “Kennedy employs a disapproving tone and strong diction in order to clearly achieve his goal in making the steel companies reverse the increase.”

· “Throughout his speech in which he condemned companies for raising steel prices, Kennedy repeatedly appeals to a sense of communal sacrifice and collective responsibility in order to rally his everyman audience around this ostensible cause for outrage.”

o.d:

· “Museums must consider what types of topics and issues they want to elevate to public consciousness. Museums have a responsibility to start a larger dialogue about their collections.”

Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Fail to address the rhetorical choices the writer of the passage makes.

· Describe or repeat the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Johnson writes a letter to a woman about her son.”

Make a claim but do not address the writer’s rhetorical choices

· “Johnson does not want to support the woman’s request because he believes it is inappropriate.”

Repeat provided information from the passage

· “Johnson says that ‘the excesses of hope must be expiated by pain.’”

Responses that earn this point:

· Respond to the prompt rather than restate or rephrase the prompt and clearly articulate a defensible thesis about the rhetorical choices Johnson makes to convey his message that he will deny the woman’s request.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible thesis that analyzes the writer’s rhetorical choices

· “Johnson’s description of hope and happiness as well as his reliance on the words no and not supports his denial of the woman’s request for her son.”

· “Johnson frames his response to the woman as a series of practical reasons for why he is not an appropriate choice to seek patronage for her son.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on summary or description of a passage rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention rhetorical choices with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning[COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one rhetorical choice in the passage contributes to the writer’s argument, purpose, or message [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an argument.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple rhetorical choices in the passage contribute to the writer’s argument, purpose, or message [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an argument.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of rhetorical choices contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation.

· Only hint at or suggest other arguments (“While some may argue that…” OR “Some people say…”).

· Examine individual rhetorical choices but do not examine the relationships among different choices throughout the passage.

· Oversimplify complexities in the passage.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the analysis.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation by doing any of the following:

1. Explaining the significance or relevance of the writer’s rhetorical choices (given the rhetorical situation).

2. Explaining a purpose or function of the passage’s complexities or tensions.

3. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Do not take a position

· “Is safety better than freedom? It just depends.”

Address the topic of the prompt but are not defensible – it is an obvious fact stated as a claim

· “H.L. Mencken believes that people only want to be safe.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Respond to the prompt by taking a position on the extent to which freedom and safety are valued in contemporary society rather than restate or rephrase the prompt.

· Clearly take a position rather than just stating that there are pros/cons.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible position that responds to the prompt

· “Freedom is a truly difficult concept with which to grapple. People only want to believe that they have freedom and free choice. A desire for safety always comes first.”

· “Does being free mean that one has choice of religion and type of government? The type of freedoms mentioned previously do not apply to mankind if mankind is not safe and is at risk for danger. It is human nature to choose safety over freedom as shown by various examples .”

Present a defensible position that responds to the prompt

· “Becoming a locavore will produce a healthier and more efficient America.”

· “Communities should consider local health needs and a range of financial obstacles so that they can effectively support healthy food first and local food second.”

Restate the prompt

Make a claim, but do not address the writer’s rhetorical choices

Repeat provided information from the passage

· “According to Jahren, anyone can be a scientist.”

· “Jahren gives the reader instructions and addresses the reader as ‘a scientist’ to present her work as interesting, important, and accessible to readers who don’t necessarily have a scientific background.”

· “Using extended parallels between human activities and the activities of nature, Jahren encourages her audience to recognize the importance of the natural processes she studies.”

o.d: The response demonstrates any of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Fail to address the rhetorical choices the writer of the passage makes.

· Describe or repeat the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In 1964, Senator Dirksen made strong rhetorical choices to achieve his purpose of persuading his fellow senators.”

Make a claim but do not address the writer’s rhetorical choices

· “Dirksen’s main point is that the senators have a duty to be responsible and enact civil rights legislation.”

Repeat provided information from the passage

· “In Dirksen’s speech, he explains that ‘nothing is eternal except change.’”

Responses that earn this point:

· Respond to the prompt rather than restate or rephrase the prompt and clearly articulate a defensible thesis about the rhetorical choices Dirksen makes to achieve his purpose of persuading his fellow senators to enact cloture and support the civil rights bill.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible thesis that analyzes the writer’s rhetorical choices

· “Some of those rhetorical choices that Dirksen makes in his speech were amplifications, anaphora, alliteration, analogy, and antiphrasis to make a point on why his colleagues should enact cloture and support the civil rights bill. He also makes those devices because he wants to prove a point on why the civil rights bill can have a huge impact on society.”

· “Dirksen employs rhetorical questions and appeals to authority to convince his fellow senators, mainly the republican senators, to enact the cloture rule and vote on the bill."

· “In Senator Dirksen’s speech he uses tone and allusion to convince the senate to enact the cloture rule."

o.d: The response demonstrates any of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Fail to address the rhetorical choices the writer of the passage makes.

· Describe or repeat the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In this passage Catt uses rhetorical devices to memorialize Susan B. Anthony.”

Make a claim but do not address the writer’s rhetorical choices

· “Due to Anthony’s confidence and strength in pushing for the 19th Amendment, she changed the future for all women.”

Repeat provided information from the passage

· “Catt memorializes Susan B. Anthony by saying that her ‘eighty-six years measure a movement whose results have been more far-reaching in the change of conditions, social, civil and political, than those of any war revolution since history began.’”

Responses that earn this point:

· Respond to the prompt rather than restate or rephrase the prompt and clearly articulate a defensible thesis about the rhetorical choices Catt makes to achieve her purpose of praising and memorializing Susan B. Anthony.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible thesis that analyzes the writer’s rhetorical choices

· “It was with these sophisticated and masterful structures that Carrie Chapman Catt was able to commemorate Anthony’s effect on the women’s suffrage movement, and the world.”

· “Chapman Catt, uses facts about our new reality, and about the dedication and optimism of Susan B. Anthony, to show the world that Susan will forever live on in history as she changed the world for the better.”

· “Catt uses comparisons and narratives to paint her subject as a titan among history, a name to be remembered positively.”

· “Throughout Adlai’s Personal address toward Eleanor Roosevelt, he kept a stern and empowered/ inspired tone throughout his address while making it clear how connected Eleanor was to all.”

· “To highlight Roosevelt’s tireless efforts to enhance the lives of all, Stevenson skillfully integrated his personal connection to her, her accomplishments, her ability to reignite hope in the hearts of all to memorialize Roosevelt and inspire others to push forward with her accomplishments.”

Examples that do not earn this point:

· “In the nonfiction book Word by Word: The Secret Life of Dictionaries, Stamper makes strong rhetorical choices to introduce the reader to the book.”

Make a claim but do not address the writer’s rhetorical choices

· “Stamper argues that trying to understand language can be difficult and working as a lexicographer is not straightforward.”

Repeat provided information from the passage

· “In the book Word by Word: the secret life of dictionaries by Kory Stamper, Stamper explains that ‘As we grow, we grind words into finer grist.’”

Responses that earn this point:

· Respond to the prompt rather than restate or rephrase the prompt and clearly articulate a defensible thesis about the rhetorical choices Stamper makes to achieve her purpose of introducing the reader to the book.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible thesis that analyzes the writer’s rhetorical choices

· “Stamper uses hypotheticals to allow the audience to grasp her stance on the particularities of the English language, vivid and relatable imagery which will enable the audience to understand the many connections that are made in the human mind, and an appeal to ethos which will encourage her audience to trust her credibility and allow her to achieve her goal in introducing her book.”

· “Stamper breaks down how we learn and store language information down to its basics, using examples that we all have experienced while learning a language, in order to preface her book and allow each reader to view language on the same level.”

· “Kory Stamper uses pathos, hyperbole, and metaphor to be able to introduce her readers to the technique of writing a dictionary.”

o.d: The response demonstrates any of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Fail to address the rhetorical choices the writer of the passage makes.

· Describe or repeat the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Patrick made a lot of rhetorical choices in his message to convey about America being a land of opportunity.”

Make a claim but do not address the writer’s rhetorical choices

· “Patrick focuses on America’s journey to justice, instead of the past injustices; in doing so, he says that America’s efforts to correct their wrongdoings established a country where he could follow his dreams.”

Repeat provided information from the passage

· “Deval Patrick recounts the struggles and the ‘improbable journey’ the founders of America went through in order to build America as we know it.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Respond to the prompt rather than restate or rephrase the prompt and clearly articulate a defensible thesis about the rhetorical choices Patrick makes to convey his message about America being a land of opportunity.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible thesis that analyzes the writer’s rhetorical choices

· “By highlighting advances that have been made, alluding to the start of America, and talking about a strong example of opportunity, Patrick is able to truly show how many opportunities America provides.”

· “In his speech after taking the governor’s oath of office, Deval Patrick’s tone is one of hope. Patrick chooses to organize his speech around the history and ideals of American citizenship. As a result, his speech suggests that opportunities are widely available to those who seek them.”

· “Patrick in his oath intends to convey to his citizens of Massachusetts their destiny to succeed as a state by appealing to a patriotic sense of emotion and an important sense of ethics which reminds the audience of the cultural and historical significance of their state.”

o.af:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

o.d:

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one rhetorical choice in the passage contributes to the writer’s argument, purpose, or message
o.af:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an argument.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple rhetorical choices in the passage contribute to the writer’s argument, purpose, or message
o.af:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an argument.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of rhetorical choices contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

Restate the prompt

  • “While laws could be put in place to limit light pollution, doing so could impact safety in a community.”

Address the topic of the prompt but do not take a position

  • “Light pollution is a problem that not many people think about, but there are many factors a community needs to consider when deciding how to address it.”

Address the topic of the prompt but state an obvious fact as a claim

  • “Like any form of pollution, light pollution is bad.”

Responses that earn this point:

  • Respond to the prompt by developing a position on the factors a community should consider when deciding whether to address concerns about light pollution, rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. Clearly take a position rather than just stating there are pros/cons.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible position that responds to the prompt

  • “When considering what to do about light pollution, a community should think about public safety, environmental cost, and biological effects on animals and people.”

  • “Although artificial lighting can have some negative effects on both humans and animals, communities should not ignore the overwhelming benefits to public safety that it can provide.”

  • “Communities should consider both the perceived and actual effects of ‘making streets safer’ that increased artificial lighting can provide and weigh them against the environmental and biological costs of light pollution.”

  • Describe or repeat the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

  • “Louise Erdrich, an author who writes about Native American characters, writes eloquently about owning an independent bookstore that features Indigenous literature.”

Make a claim but do not address the writer’s rhetorical choices

  • “In her essay, Erdrich argues that small and independent bookstores are vital to a democratic society.”

Repeat provided information from the passage

  • “Louise Erdrich claims that independent bookstores can perform multiple functions in modern life, such as bolstering democratic ideals or being places of solace for a community.”

Responses that earn this point:

  • Respond to the prompt rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt and clearly articulate a defensible thesis about the rhetorical choices Erdrich makes to convey her message about the role of bookstores in modern life.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible thesis that analyzes the writer’s rhetorical choices

  • “Erdrich uses references to history and famous people, comparisons, and personal stories to argue that books and bookstores mean a lot to different people.”

  • “In her narrative, Erdrich recounts her own personal observations of people in bookstores to support her claim that ‘people come to the bookstore for solace, calm, and balance.’”

  • “Erdrich makes allusions to historical events, uses personal examples, and employs a warm, engaging tone to convey her message about the importance of small bookstores in modern life.”

o.d: The response demonstrates any of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Do not take a position, or the position is vague or must be inferred.

· Equivocate or summarize others’ arguments but not the student’s (e.g., some people say it’s good, some people say it’s bad).

· State an obvious fact rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Some people think that STEM classes should be taught in schools today, but others think that it’s not necessary or effective.”

Address the topic of the prompt but do not take a position

· “STEM education has increased in the United States as more and more corporations are hiring students who have mastery of STEM subjects.”

Address the topic of the prompt but state an obvious fact as a claim

· “Concerned that American students are lagging behind internationally in STEM disciplines, U.S. schools are starting to put more emphasis on STEM education.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Respond to the prompt by developing a position on the value, if any, of initiatives to improve STEM education and increase the number of students interested in the STEM disciplines, rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. Clearly take a position rather than just stating there are pros/cons.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible position that responds to the prompt

· “The United States should place more emphasis on STEM initiatives so that American students can keep up with international competition for jobs.”

· “While an education in STEM disciplines is important, students should still take classes in the humanities, arts, and social sciences to be more well-rounded in their education and be more prepared for life after school.”

· “STEM education is an overrated trend that will not last. In fact, many employers look for qualities and skills that are not only taught in STEM classes.”

Responses that do not earn this point:

  • Only restate the prompt.

  • Do not take a position, or the position is vague or must be inferred.

  • Equivocate or summarize others’ arguments but not the student’s (e.g., some people say it’s good, some people say it’s bad).

  • State an obvious fact rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

  • “Many researchers believe that English should be the standard language for scientific publications, but some scientists who are not native English speakers feel this is unfair.”

Address the topic of the prompt but do not take a position

  • “When universities and other scientific institutions are deciding how to support scientists who cannot write in English, they must consider many important factors.”

Address the topic of the prompt but state an obvious fact as a claim

  • “While English is the dominant language of science, a large percentage of the world’s scientists are speakers of languages other than English, which can create a language barrier.”

Responses that earn this point:

  • Respond to the prompt by developing a position on the most important factors that should be considered when deciding how best to support the careers of scientists from different linguistic backgrounds, rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. Clearly take a position rather than just stating there are pros/cons.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible position that responds to the prompt

  • “The most important factors universities and academic journals need to consider when deciding how best to support non-native English-speaking scientists are cost, access, and bias.”

  • “Although most scientific researchers agree that a common language is necessary for their field, expecting scientists from non-English speaking backgrounds to shoulder the responsibility of learning how to communicate effectively in English while also trying to conduct actual research is an unreasonable burden.”

  • “The universities, organizations, and publications that benefit from using English as the universal language of scientific research should offer support, such as mentoring, proofreading, and English-language tutorials, to researchers from different linguistic backgrounds.”

  • “People can be persuaded by many things.”

Responses that earn this point:

  • Respond to the prompt by taking a position on the extent to which Curbelo’s claim about persuading others is valid, rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. Clearly take a position rather than just stating that there are pros/cons.

Examples that earn this point:

Present a defensible position that responds to the prompt

  • “Former U.S. Representative Curbelo correctly points out that scare tactics are not effective when trying to foster collaboration.”

  • “Although trying to frighten someone into changing their mind might be considered bullying in many instances, there are some situations where the only way to make people see reason is to present them with the unpleasant, and often scary, truth.”

Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

  • Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

o.d: The response demonstrates any of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

  • Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

  • May be just opinion with no evidence or evidence that is irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

  • Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

  • Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

  • Tend to focus on summary of evidence rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

  • Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

  • Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

  • Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

  • May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

  • May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

  • Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

  • Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

  • Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

  • Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

  • Focus on the importance of specific details to build an argument.

  • Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

  • Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

  • Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

  • Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

  • Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

  • Focus on the importance of specific details to build an argument.

  • Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

  • This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not meet the criteria for one point.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

  • Attempt to contextualize their argument, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“In a world where . . .” OR “Since the beginning of time . . .”).

  • Only hint at or suggest other arguments (“While some may argue that . . .” OR “Some people say . . .”).

  • Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation by doing any of the following:

1. Crafting a nuanced argument by consistently identifying and exploring complexities or tensions.

2. Articulating the implications or limitations of an argument (either the student’s argument or an argument related to the prompt) by situating it within a broader context.

3. Making effective rhetorical choices that consistently strengthen the force and impact of the student’s argument.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.
